text: It looks long but the data is just a Julia matrix, so you can evaluate it and at the bottom is 2000% error predictions from LIBSVM :scream:

text: So maybe negative results might be useful?  Just happened to be playing with <https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cpc.2020.107663> (rational polynomial fits) and the best I could do was ~1848% error with a (3, 5) rational polynomial.  My feeling is that you will need a lot more data to fit a model with 9 parameters. (now there's a surprise)

elements.text: So maybe negative results might be useful?  Just happened to be playing with

(rational polynomial fits) and the best I could do was ~1848% error with a (3, 5) rational polynomial.  My feeling is that you will need a lot more data to fit a model with 9 parameters. (now there's a surprise)

text: I think its a bit optimistic to just throw data with such a skewed outcome into a model. A model would need to be really motivated to predict anything beyond the value 10 when 67% of the data is below it and the rest is widely spread across 10-270. I dont think collecting more data is the first avenue to pursue here. did you try to subsample the observations where Y < 10 (or supersample the others)? it might become a little more plug and play
